awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Muscle-Inspired Load-Adaptive Actuation for Compliant Robotics
awd_abstract_narration:
This Faculty Early Career Development Program (CAREER) project will advance the national health, welfare, and security through scientific advancements in the field of biologically-inspired robotics favorable for wearable technology and exoskeletons. The research will make important contributions to society by increasing robot energy efficiency and performance while simultaneously improving human-robot interaction compatibility and safety through the use of inherently soft actuators. Actuators are critical component of a machine or robot that are responsible for moving and controlling a mechanism or components of a system. Current robotic actuators are poorly suited to wearable or human-assistive applications because they are inefficient when used in slow, variable-speed motions like moving an arm or leg. In addition, they create human safety hazards due to their stiffness and rigid motions. This research will create a new type of actuator that is inspired by human muscle tissues, which contain thousands of fibers that are selectively recruited to provide only the amount of force needed for a given task. Engineering artificial muscles to incorporate this concept of selective recruitment will allow the robot to consume less energy, therefore increasing battery life and range. It will also allow the same actuator to generate both gentle, precise motion as well as high-force, high-speed motion, depending on the task, while also incorporating soft construction and controllable stiffness. This new approach will help make assistive robotics safer, more comfortable, and more compatible with human physiology, all of which will provide more rapid and effective recovery for those suffering from debilitating injuries or disabilities. This research lends itself well to outreach opportunities to work with young people who suffer from disabilities; the outreach activities will help inspire them and show them how engineering can be used to improve their lives and the lives of those around them.

Improvements in actuator efficiency and performance can be made by implementing the biologically-inspired concept of orderly recruitment to create an integrated fluidic artificial muscle tissue that contains selectable actuation elements of different sizes. This tissue can dynamically adapt to changes in load by recruiting different combinations of actuators. This orderly recruitment scheme conserves energy by reducing working fluid consumption and minimizing throttling losses. It also allows for a wide gamut of force generation and fast response time due to reduced flow rate demand. The goals of this research are to (1) understand the relationships between recruitment state, pressure, force, contraction, and velocity for selective-recruitment fluidic artificial muscle tissues; (2) establish the effects of topology on performance and create a framework for optimizing tissues to robot operating tasks and requirements; (3) understand implications of recruitment control architecture; and (4) demonstrate bandwidth improvements, variable compliance, and energetic savings on a walking robot platform.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Overview: This project has created innovations in the dynamics and control of robots that physically interact with humans by modeling, optimizing, and validating a new paradigm for muscle-inspired soft actuators. Existing actuators, while well-developed for traditional applications like industrial pick and place robots, are poorly suited to wearable or human-assistive robots due to mismatches in compliance and poor system-level efficiency during low-frequency and time-varying motions. We proposed a variable-recruitment actuation and control strategy inspired by the motor unit architecture of natural muscles. The proposed compliant artificial muscle bundles, which are powered and controlled hydraulically, adaptively match their active geometry to instantaneous load for improved energy efficiency, bandwidth, stiffness control, and failure tolerance.

Intellectual Merit: This research work has made the following contributions to the scientific and engineering community:

  • We developed advanced fabrication techniques for soft integrated fluidic artificial muscle (FAM) bundles.
  • We developed and validated mathematical models to quantify interaction effects between active and inactive FAM chambers.
  • We developed a compact orderly recruitment valve (ORV) for the sequential recruitment of motor units within an artificial muscle bundle.
  • We developed analytical models and experimental characterizations of physiologically-inspired bipennate FAM bundle topologies.
  • We fabricated a testing platform for pennate topology FAM bundles suitable for various boundary conditions.
  • We developed a tendon-based resistive force mitigation strategy in variable recruitment FAM bundles and analyzed its effects on overall actuation energy efficiency and volumetric energy density.
  • We developed a recruitment state transition control strategy that compensates for the resistive effects of inactive or partially activated motor units.
  • We performed system-level analysis of efficiencies and bandwidth limits for a variable recruitment FAM bundle model including inter-FAM effects under variable pump displacement operating conditions.
  • We built a linear hydraulic dynamometer (LHD) and used it to test and demonstrate a model-based variable recruitment controller.
  • We designed an LHD-based hardware-in-the-loop dynamic load emulator for testing artificial muscle bundle actuators and control algorithms on a variety of different robotic systems with variable parameters.
  • We developed FAMs with tailorable radial stiffness to allow inactive units to passively draw in fluid, thereby increasing the efficiency of the bundle through passive priming.
  • We created a framework for optimizing FAM bundle topology within specified geometric bounds to maximize bundle force and stroke and establish the effects of topology on system performance.

Broader impacts: The research effort benefited society through the STEM outreach and education activities carried out by the PI’s laboratory:

  • This project has provided research experience and mentoring to a total of 24 students from high school to the doctoral level including five doctoral students, thirteen undergraduate students, one visiting (virtual) graduate student, and four high school students who gained access to the research.
  • This project has provided valuable opportunities to underrepresented groups in STEM, as we have had two female doctoral students, five female undergraduate students, and one Black high school student work on this project.
  • We had the opportunity to work with four local high school students through a mentorship program with the North Carolina School of Science and Math (NCSSM), where they participated in semester-long research internships and received hands-on training to design and fabricate conceptual prototypes.
  • We have collaborated with the NC State Department of Biomedical Engineering to develop a summer camp outreach module to teach high school students about our work and give them hands-on experience with FAMs and variable recruitment actuators. Furthermore, we participated in the Medical Bridge outreach summer camp for underrepresented students to introduce soft fluidic actuators for potential applications in medical assistive devices.
  • We partnered with The Science House, a STEM outreach unit within the College of Sciences at NC State, to design and lead a day-long outreach activity for around 50 high school students with disabilities. We taught the fundamental science behind FAMs, discussed their potential applications, and guided the students through a hands-on activity where they each fabricated several FAMs and used them to actuate the fingers on a 3D-printed hand.

This work will also benefit society by addressing the need for safer, more energy efficient, and more compliant actuation with applications in both industrial and biomedical robotics. The concept of variable recruitment can be leveraged beyond fluidic artificial muscles in a variety of other applications where more efficient actuation and variable stiffness properties are desired. The topology optimization tools developed to study myriad actuator designs enabled by artificial muscle bundles lay the foundation for studying the emergent behavior of biological muscle architecture. The work completed under this project may also help enable rehabilitative devices that can be better interfaced with humans, achieve longer untethered operating endurance, and be more readily tailored to individual patients.
